news_header: The Real Living Wage in the UK is increasing by 5%, benefiting nearly half a million workers, while the National Minimum Wage and National Living Wage have also seen significant increases.
news_text: The Real Living Wage in the UK will rise by 5%, benefiting around 475,000 workers, with the London Living Wage increasing by 5.3%. The National Minimum Wage and National Living Wage also increased in April, with the latter now set at £11.44 per hour for those aged 21 and over. Full-time minimum wage workers will see an annual pay rise of £1,800, while 21-year-olds moving to the main rate will get an increase of £2,300. The rates for younger workers have also risen. Employers must implement these new rates by May 2025. The Real Living Wage is not legally required but is based on living costs, overseen by the Living Wage Foundation. Since 2011, the scheme has provided nearly £3.5 billion in additional wages to low-paid workers.
